fact: Exoplanets are planets that orbit stars outside our solar system. The first confirmed discovery of an exoplanet was made in 1992, orbiting a pulsar named PSR B1257+12, making them some of the oldest known planetary systems.

The smallest exoplanet discovered so far is smaller than Earth's moon, while the largest ones, known as 'super-Jupiters,' are several times the size of Jupiter. This highlights the incredible diversity of planetary sizes in the universe.

Some exoplanets are so close to their stars that they complete an orbit in just a few hours. These planets, called 'hot Jupiters,' have scorching surface temperatures reaching thousands of degrees Celsius.

The Kepler Space Telescope, launched in 2009, revolutionized our understanding of exoplanets, discovering over 2,600 confirmed planets during its mission and revealing that planets are common in the universe.
One of the strangest exoplanets discovered is HD 189733b, which has winds blowing at speeds of up to 8,700 km/h and rains molten glass sideways due to its scorching atmosphere.

Some exoplanets, like Kepler-22b, are located in the 'habitable zone' of their stars, where conditions might allow liquid water to exist. These planets are prime candidates in the search for extraterrestrial life.
Trappist-1 is a star system with seven Earth-sized exoplanets. Three of these planets are in the habitable zone, making it one of the most exciting discoveries in the search for life beyond Earth.
55 Cancri e is a super-Earth exoplanet that might be composed largely of diamond. Its high carbon content and intense pressure make it one of the universe's most dazzling worlds.
Rogue planets are exoplanets that wander through space without orbiting any star. These mysterious worlds drift in the darkness, possibly forming in stellar systems before being ejected.
Scientists use methods like the transit method and radial velocity to detect exoplanets. These techniques allow them to study tiny wobbles or dimming of a star's light caused by orbiting planets.
